Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Using Data Mining to Optimally Customize Therapy for Individuals with Autism
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project includes innovations in data mining and the treatment of autism. Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) therapy is the gold standard in treating autism. Applying data analytics to data from ABA therapy sessions will contribute in several important ways: a) patterns may be discerned across individuals with autism to better understand variations in autism and create therapies to target these differences; b) patterns may be matched with other data, such as genomic data, to identify cross-patterns that may be useful in better understanding autism and ways to improve therapy; and c) the frontiers of data mining will be expanded to provide guidance in real time. This project will have the following societal impacts: 1) many more individuals with autism across the globe will receive early, quality, cost-effective treatment regimens that will enable them to live more fulfilled lives and reach their full potential; 2) families whose children are good candidates for treatment and receive it will experience reduced stress and better family life; and 3) the additional lifetime cost of not effectively treating children with autism, which is approximately ten-fold the cost of treatment, will be reduced.

The proposed project is to extract informative sequential patterns from trial sequences of an individual student, use them to accurately predict trial outcomes, and utilize the predictive model to provide individualized recommendations about how to modify trials and steps of student training. To achieve this goal, predictive data mining will be used. To develop accurate predictive models, the project will build on a large body of recent work in machine learning on temporal predictive modeling and sequential pattern mining, including some of the previous results of the project team. Special attention will be paid to the recent work in educational data mining and intelligent tutoring. Specific key objectives include: 1) Representation of Trial Data for Predictive Modeling: how to represent the raw sequential data in a way that is most suitable for prediction modeling; 2) Development of Models for Prediction of Trial Outcomes: which model is the most suitable for prediction of outcomes in sequential trials and how to train a prediction model from highly-dimensional multi-therapy recipient sequential data; and 3) Guiding Therapy of a Child with Autism Based on an Early Classification Model: how to adjust and extend the previously developed approach by the project team to guide trials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Guiding Technologies is developing unique, transformative technology that provides real-time guidance to instructors, continually updated based on student performance, which will improve the quality and consistency of Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) Therapy, the gold standard for treating autism. The guidance provided is tailored to instructor needs based on experience and preference, e.g., novice instructors and family members can choose detailed step-by-step guidance that helps them overcome the complexity of ABA therapy and enables them to provide consistent therapy right from the start, while also improving their skills. A by-product of using this technology is the capture of high quality, contextually rich student performance data.

 

Real-world trials at a leading regional autism therapy service provider greatly improved the technology and proved its potential to support instructors during ABA therapy and capture high quality, detailed session-level data not usually captured during therapy. Using visualization and predictive modeling techniques with the captured data, data analytics provided valuable insights across all training periods and individual training sessions. For example, for the first time, Bancroft supervisors could see patterns where one especially active student usually progressed well for the first 20 minutes of a standard 30-minute session but his motivation and concomitant performance then dropped off. Based on this information, supervisors adjusted the therapy process for this student to give a break after twenty minutes and this has greatly improved the student’s therapy progress. This demonstrates the potential for advanced data capture and analyses to customize and improve ABA therapy on a child-by-child basis.

The main goal of the data analytics in this project was to utilize the collected logs from multiple sessions with multiple therapy recipients and multiple instructors to better understand the progress of therapy, uncover hidden patterns, and ultimately assist supervisors in selecting and designing trials.  As the technology evolved and we started working with a large regional autism service provider and collecting and analyzing data from the actual trials, some of our understanding about data properties, important questions to be asked, and how the data should be analyzed changed. As a result, we modified some of the originally stated objectives. We placed a larger focus on data understanding, which included data visualization and statistical data analysis, and a somewhat reduced focus on predictive modeling.

After examining the existing data visualization software and the research literature, we concluded that visualization of rich longitudinal data, such as the trial data collected in this project is still an open research problem. A few recent papers on visualization of medical records data gave us some clues about appropriate ways to visualize the autism trial data. Eventually, we developed two ways to visualize trial data: one is providing a view of all trials within a single day and another is providing an aggregated view of all historical sessions. We showed this data visualization to several Bancroft supervisors and instructors and their feedback was positive.

Given the insight obtained from the visual data analytics, we proceeded with exploratory and statistical analysis. In particular, we were interested in learning what factors might impact the success rate of any given trial set. The factors that we examined included temporal variability, impact of instructors, and order of program elements.
